courseTitle: Latin American Studies: Overview of Field
courseDescription: The objective of this course is to enhance students’ understanding of the region of Latin America. It will seek to engage more closely with the culture, politics, social and human landscape of the region through the concepts of land, peoples, exchange and creativity. Readings, lectures, film viewings, and discussions will constitute integral components of the course and draw upon the work of various academic disciplines and artistic traditions. The course insists on the inter-disciplinary nature of Latin American Studies and the different insights offered by its different constituent disciplines.  All readings and lectures are in English.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analyzing films and other multimedia sources
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and respecting diverse cultural perspectives
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of readings and lectures
Interpreting cultural, political, and social dynamics
Analyzing artistic traditions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for readings and lectures

courseTitle: Comparative Caribbean and Latin American Culture and Civilization
courseDescription: An introductory, panoramic course that covers a wide, but representative array of eras in Latin American history (colonial, post-colonial, present-day) and problems (indigenous groups, exploitation of the land and natural resources, political tendencies, and U.S. sphere of influence). Literary and historical readings will be paired with other media in order to discuss issues of colonialism, wars of independence, revolutions, exile, migration, race, class, and gender. All readings and lectures are in English.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of historical and political issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of historical and political issues
Analysis of race, class, and gender issues
Identification and analysis of political tendencies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and synthesizing complex historical information

courseDescription: This course will explore through poetry, songs, music, stories, (auto)biographical accounts and novels the importance, creativity, and meaning produced by people of African descent living in or from Latin America. It will focus on the Afro- Latinx narrative forms coming out of Ecuador, Brazil, Colombia, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Mexico, Puerto Rico and the United states. Through examining the narrative expressions of Blackness throughout regions of Latin America students can consider the relationship that social historical processes such as colonialism, nation-making and continued racism have on narrative production. Key to this course will be examining the ways race and gender/sexuality intersect within the multiple forms of expression of the Afro-Latinx community. Readings and lectures in English.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding the impact of social historical processes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating about race and gender issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical reading and analysis
Understanding complex social issues
Evaluating the impact of colonialism and racism
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on race and gender
Formulating arguments based on literary analysis

courseDescription: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to Brazil’s regions and cultural history, to Brazil’s unique place in the Americas, and to its place in the world of Portuguese language. It presents major topics in the panorama of Brazilian cultural history and civilization from 1500 to the present through readings on regions, cultures, peoples, and arts, including the architects of Brazil’s national cultural identity, its chronological development, and modern self-description. Topics include discovery and rediscovery of Brazil, baroque architecture, romanticism and empire, regionalism, immigration, urbanization, and modernization. The main texts draw on a cultural history of Brazil through selected writings by major authors and scholars. All lectures and readings in English.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging in intellectual discussions on cultural history
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical reading and analysis of historical texts
Historical interpretation and synthesis
Analysis of cultural development and transformation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Synthesizing complex historical and cultural information

courseDescription: Course focuses particularly on works produced by the three major groups of U.S. Latinx (Mexican Americans or Chicanos, Puerto Ricans or Nuyoricans, and Cuban Americans) during the 20th and 21st centuries but will also include some pieces representative of other Latinx identities. Students will analyze works from a range of genres and cultural expressions including poetry, fiction, memoirs, film, and performance, along with recent literary and cultural theory works. Topics to be discussed include identity formation and negotiation in terms of language, race, gender, sexuality, and class; the colonial subject; diaspora and emigration; the marketing of the Latinx identity; and activism through art. Lectures and readings are in English.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of literary works
Interpretation of cultural expressions
Understanding and analysis of identity formation and negotiation

courseTitle: Topics in Latin American Area Studies
courseDescription: Investigation of special topics on Latin America.  All readings and lectures are in English.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of digital resources for information gathering
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate on Latin American topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of readings
Interpretation of complex sociocultural contexts

courseDescription: This course evaluates human rights movements, mechanisms, and their impacts in Latin America. Students will examine different human rights crises to understand how these events have shaped the region and what the response to them has been. The class is less a study of the specific legal mechanisms used in human rights practice and more a study of how human rights have evolved as a discourse and political strategy in struggles for justice. It adopts a more anthropological and geographic approach to understanding human rights theory and practice. All readings and lectures in English.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of human rights cases
Understanding and applying human rights theory
Analyzing political strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and navigating political and legal systems

courseTitle: Latin American Thinkers Changing Culture and Politics
courseDescription: In this course students will study the ideas of some important Latin American thinkers whose work has helped to shape Latin American history and society from Independence in the early 19th Century to the present. Even though special attention will be paid to some writers, works by a larger number of intellectuals will be analyzed as a way of understanding some of the central ideas in Latin American culture: “mestizaje,” nationalism and popular culture, among others. All readings and lectures in English.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking
Analyzing complex societal issues
Comparative analysis

courseDescription: This course will explore some of the unique contradictions shaping Brazilian reality as related to notions of race and culture by tracing the history of race relations in the ongoing transformation of Brazilian culture, examining such key examples and events as slavery and the plantation economy, popular music, Carnival, populism, racial democracy, affirmative action, and urban and rural violence. All readings and lectures in English.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of historical and cultural findings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of historical events
Critical evaluation of racial and cultural dynamics
Examination and interpretation of popular culture
